{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3683876,"name":"Martin Pirringer","username":"mpirringer","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/mpirringer/{size}/124489_2.png","created_at":"2025-07-18T16:35:26.996Z","cooked":"

PXL_20250717_2025370241920×2550 447 KB

Well all wheels are touching the ground which is good lol. Its a ton of different parts some tpu, some petg. On a chassis made of 2020 the gantry in the middle might look like an ender x gantry to you and its close as some of the parts came from old printers and some from stuff I bought and had lying around.

Now the whole thing - uless I get some FTC/FRC donations will be run by an ESP32 S3 I am in the process of designing a board to run 8 pmw, 8 quadrature encoders (for closed loops) 8 servos - 16 switches. So some I/O multiplexing/expanding will happen. The board is to be controlled by either usb using a custom flavor of G code and probably more often via WIFI through a web interface. So I am going to be busy for a while with that.
Now I went through quite a bit of filament on this as none of the parts are iteration 1. And I have a feeling some of the parts need to be iterated further

Still intend on doing the FRC version but for now FTC it is mainly cause the FTC bot is much lighter (15lb compared to FRC which with battery runs 120-150 lb) And my current health situation makes lifting things above 20 lb difficult so for me its much easier disassembling and reassembling a 15-20lb bot than a 150 lb one. Once all the kinks are worked out the scaling up to FRC size should be much less work.

The ESP32 setup will be able to be controlled by a roborio. The reason I don’t just use the roborio I have by itself is as it does not have enough I/O. Now it could happen with sparkmax or talon srx controllers but I got victor SPX and 883/884 controllers and they don’t have integrated encoders/limit switches etc. And with that you run out of I/O quickly.
